data.title: Video: Jill Hennessy busking in Toronto
data.meta_description: Jill Hennessy is known widely from her roles on TV (
data.text:

Jill Hennessy is known widely from her roles on TV (Law and Order

,

Crossing Jordan

), and from her work in film, including the movie

Small Town Murder Songs

, which premiered this week at the Toronto International Film Festival.

However, before she got into acting, the actress was making music on the streets and subways of Toronto as a busker. Earlier this year she followed up on her first career and released her debut album, Ghost in my Head

Article content

.

Here, she discusses how the album began:

“It was kind of like the Wizard of Oz, where you just keep meeting people along the yellow brick road. One of the friends who was on me to start writing was a guy named Barry from Lubbock, Texas. He and I had always covered Springsteen together and would play guitar every time we hung out. So I finally called him and [told him] I started writing. He said what kind of instrumentation are you looking for. I said I’d love cello, accordion, lead guitar. He said: ‘I know three guys just outside of Texas who just opened a studio. They’re really good friends of mine and you’re going to love them’.

On a leap of faith we flew down to Austin and met these guys . I played one of my songs and they jumped right in and it was spectacular . So good in fact we rented a studio two nights later and recorded the whole night. We recorded five of the songs from the album and just about all 5 of those remain pretty much intact on the finished product. It was a long night.”

So, with her roots in mind, when Hennessy came through Toronto with her new film, we asked her to return to the streets she started busking on, and she agreed. Here, she and her twin sister Jacqueline play a few songs from the album (and make a few bucks) near the hub of the festival: TIFF’s Bell Lightbox.

Jill Hennessy’s Ghost in My Head is available now. Small Town Murder Songs plays Friday night at the AMC in Toronto as part of TIFF, and opens across Canada later this autumn,
